Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploiting Prokaryotic Proteins to Improve Plant Photosynthetic Efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration: Photorespiration can account for yield losses of 25-50% in C3 plants, which include rice, wheat and soybean, three of the top four crops in terms of global grain production. Photorespiration occurs because oxygen and carbon dioxide (CO2) compete for the same acceptor molecule in photosynthesis. The process can be very simply inhibited by increasing the concentration of CO2. When CO2 is increased artificially in greenhouses or in open fields, very significant yield increases are obtained. However, artificially elevating CO2 over millions of acres of fields is not feasible. Some cyanobacteria solve this problem by confining the fixation of carbon to a structure termed a carboxysome, where localization of specific enzymes cause a concentration of CO2. Although chloroplasts, which contain the photosynthetic machinery of crops, lack carboxysomes, they evolved from cyanobacteria, which were symbiotically recruited into the ancestors of todays plants and crops. This research project will provide the foundation for a synthetic biology approach in which carboxysomes will be engineered into the chloroplasts of crop plants to enhance photosynthesis. Optimization will involve manipulating a model plant that is readily transformable and the development of an in silico model of the system to evaluate the use of different proteins and the minimal system that is needed. A multidisciplinary approach will be implemented through collaboration of four research groups, each contributing complementary expertise: carboxysome genetics and assembly (Berkeley), chloroplast and nuclear transformation (Cornell), photosynthetic systems modelling (Illinois) and physiological and biochemical characterization of the whole plant (Rothamsted, Cornell and Illinois). The project will allow postdoctoral and undergraduate trainees to gain experience in an international collaborative project (All). Research resources for comparing plant and bacterial genes will be developed for use in undergraduate education (Berkeley).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants and photosynthetic bacteria known as cyanobacteria use sunlight to convert atmospheric CO2 into biologically useful organic molecules. The enzyme ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (Rubisco) carries out carbon fixation. As the name suggests, Rubisco can fix O2 instead of CO2, leading to a process termed photorespiration that reduces the efficiency of photosynthesis.  One way to improve carbon fixation is to minimize photorespiration by increasing the amount of CO2 available to the enzyme. Cyanobacteria have evolved a CO2-concentrating mechanism utilizing the carboxysome, a small compartment which encapsulates Rubisco in a protein shell, thus allowing the cells to use a faster Rubisco enzyme even though it is more sensitive to oxygen than land plant enzymes. Two undergraduates, a high school student, a graduate student and a postdoctoral associate performed experiments in order to explore the possibility that the cyanobacterial Rubisco and the carboxysome could be introduced into crop plants. We also collaborated with a group at Rothamsted Research in England, working closely with another postdoctoral associate there.  

A number of previous attempts to introduce faster versions of Rubisco versions into plants have not been successful.  We took a new approach to replace a land plant Rubisco with a cyanobacterial enzyme; we engineered genes for the cyanobacterial Rubisco into the genome located in the chloroplast, which is the organelle in the plant cell where photosynthesis occurs. We found that by adjusting the abundance of the enzyme to a sufficient level, plants fixing carbon with the cyanobacterial Rubisco could grow rapidly.  The plants containing the faster Rubisco needed extra CO2 in the air in order to grow because the entire carboxysome has not yet been engineered into the chloroplast. 

We also investigated whether genes that encode protein components of the carboxysome compartment could be expressed in the chloroplast and then result in the formation of structures. We found that we could introduce genes for three such proteins and they would self-assemble into small compartments. Future work will be needed to express all the cyanobacterial proteins needed for the entire microcompartment to surround the Rubisco and provide it with CO2 for rapid carbon fixation.  If an entire functional carboxysome is transferred into plants, the cyanobacterial Rubisco would be protected from oxygen and plants would be able to fix carbon more rapidly than they could using  leaves containing land plant Rubisco, thus improving crop yield.
